Determines whether to align the control.
true if the control should be aligned; otherwise, false.
The upper-left corner of the control is aligned according to the longest label.

Gets or sets the background color of the control.
An integer that contains a packed RGB color.
The integer that is returned contains a packed RGB color as follows:
The low-order byte contains a value for the relative intensity of red.
The second byte contains a value for green.
The third byte contains a value for blue.
The high-order byte must be zero.
The maximum value for a single byte is 255.
Determines whether the control background can be transparent.
1 if the control background can be transparent; otherwise, 0.

Gets or sets the color scheme of the control.
An integer between zero and two, inclusive.
The color scheme is defined according to the following table.
Gets or sets the configuration key that is assigned to the control.
The identifier of the configuration key that is assigned to the control.
The configuration key is used to determine whether this control can be displayed.
If the configuration key is disabled in the system, the control is not displayed in the form.
Retrieves a list that contains the IDs of configuration keys that are in effect for the control.
A list that contains the IDs of configuration keys that are in effect for the control.
The returned list does not contain duplicate IDs.
If the control is bound to a data source, the returned list of configuration key IDs also includes the configuration key ID for the table and field.
The returned list also contains any configuration key IDs that are applied to the properties, extended data type, or enumType methods.

This method is used by the reference group control to track exactly which relations produce the replacement field that is used.
It enables the reference group control to bind consistently to the controls that it contains.

Determines whether to enable or disable the object.
true if the object is enabled; otherwise, false.
The enabled property allows for controls to be enabled or disabled at run time.
For example, you can disable objects that do not apply to the current state of the application.
You can also disable a control that is used only for display purposes, such as an error message, which provides read-only information.

Retrieves a value that indicates whether the control allows for the specified level of customization.
A value from the FormAllowUserSetup enumeration that specifies the level of customization that is being queried for the control.
true if the control, design, and parent containers allow for the level of customization that is specified by the neededSetupRights parameter; otherwise, false.
The following table describes the values for the neededSetupRights parameter.
No changes can be made to the control.
If this value is set for the neededSetupRights parameter, the method always returns true.
The user can change the editable, visible, skip, label, and width properties of the control.
The user cannot move the control.
The user can change the editable, visible, skip, label, and width properties of the control.
The user can also move the control.
For this method to return true, the AllowUserSetup property for the design and all parent containers must allow for the level of access that is specified by the neededSetupRights parameter.

Gets or sets the name that is used in code to identify a form, report, table, query, or another Finance and Operations application object.

The name property value of an object must meet the following criteria to avoid code conflicts:
Can include numbers and underscore characters.
Tables cannot have the same name as other public objects, such as extended data types, base enumeration types, classes, and so on.

Sets or returns the width of the control in pixels, as specified by the user.
The number of pixels to use as the width of the control; optional.
The number of pixels that the user specified as the width of the control; 0 (zero) if the user did not specify a character width.
The userWidth method returns the width in pixels, based on six times the number of characters.
For example, if the user has specified 30 characters as the width of the control, the return value is 6 \* 30 = 180.
To specify the width of the control in characters, users can right-click the control to open the setup form where the character specification is made.

Determines whether to enable or disable the object.
true if the object is enabled; otherwise, false.
The enabled property gives for controls to be enabled or disabled at run time.
For example, you can disable objects that do not apply to the current state of the application.
You can also disable a control that is used only for display purposes, such as an error message, which provides read-only information.
Gets or sets the text color for the control to use.
An integer that contains a packed RGB color.
The integer that is returned contains a packed RGB color as follows:
The low-order byte contains a value for the relative intensity of red.
The second byte contains a value for green.
The third byte contains a value for blue.
The high-order byte must be zero.
The maximum value for a single byte is 255.

Sets or returns the width of the control in pixels, as specified by the user.
The number of pixels to use as the width of the control; optional.
The number of pixels that the user specified as the width of the control; 0 (zero) if the user did not specify a character width.
The userWidth method returns the width in pixels, based on six times the number of characters.
For example, if the user has specified 30 characters as the width of the control, the return value is 6 \* 30 = 180.
To specify the width of the control in characters, users can right-click the control to open the setup form where the character specification is made.
